docs.snippet: To the Editor: ''Punta del Este, Uruguay; Feeling at Home Among the Elite'' by Matt Gross (Frugal Traveler, Jan. 7), repeats an age-old urban legend: that water spins down a drain counterclockwise in the southern hemisphere: ''I could hear the money...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Punta del Este, Uruguay; Feeling at Home Among the Elite'' by Matt Gross (Frugal Traveler, Jan. 7), repeats an age-old urban legend: that water spins down a drain counterclockwise in the southern hemisphere: ''I could hear the money running merrily down the drain -- counterclockwise, of course: this was the Southern Hemisphere.'' There's just one problem: it ain't so.
docs.abstract: Glenn Weinstein letter on Matt Gross's January 7 Frugal Traveler column on Punta del Este, Uruguay

docs.snippet: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y....
docs.lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959. MUSIC AND DANCE Danbury Trombones de Costa Rica, trombone quartet. Feb. 3 at 8 p.m. $5 to $10. Ives Concert Hall in White Hall, 181 White Street, Western Connecticut University Midtown Campus. (203) 837-8350. East Hartford Dan Paisley and the Southern Grass, bluegrass. Feb. 3 at 7:30 p.m. $10 to $17. East Hartford Community Cultural Center, 50 Chapman Place. (860) 528-1458. Fairfield Beethoven's Symphony No. 6 and other works, presented by the American Chamber Orchestra, directed by Christopher Hisey, with Kangho Lee, cello. Friday at 8 p.m. $15; students, $10. First Presbyterian Church of Fairfield, 2475 Easton Turnpike. (203) 222-7190. Fairfield Puccini's ''Tosca,'' presented by the Bulgarian State Opera. Friday at 8 p.m. $40 to $50. Quick Center for the Arts, 1073 North Benson Road. (203) 254-4010. Greenwich ''The Spirit of Elegance,'' presented by the Greenwich Symphony Orchestra, directed by David Gilbert. Feb. 3 at 8 p.m. and Feb. 4 at 4 p.m. $25; students, $10. Greenwich High School, 10 Hillside Road. (203) 869-2664. Greenwich Inon Barnatan, piano. Jan. 28 at 4 p.m. Free. Greenwich Library, 101 West Putnam Avenue. (203) 622-7900. Middletown ''Deeply There (stories of a neighborhood)'' and ''Stay Together,'' presented by the Joe Goode Performance Group. Friday and Feb. 3 at 8 p.m. $8 to $20. Center for the Arts, Wesleyan University. (860) 685-3355. New Canaan Notes in Midwinter Concert Series: Moxie, swing ensemble. Jan. 28 at 2 p.m. Free. New Canaan Library, 151 Main Street. (203) 594-5000. New Haven Jazz on the Wharf: Steve Davis, slide trombone. Friday at 9 p.m. $15. Long Wharf Theater, 222 Sargent Drive. (203) 787-4282. New Haven ''Isn't It Romantic?'' presented by the New Haven Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Gerald Steichen. Friday at 7:30 p.m. $15 to $48. Shubert Theater, 247 College Street. (203) 624-1825. New Haven Works by Ezra Laderman, Martin Bresnick and Aaron Jay Kernis, performed by the Alianza Quartet. Monday at 8 p.m. Free. Works by Beethoven, Dvorak and Martin Bresnick, performed by the Jupiter Trio. Tuesday at 8 p.m. $13 to $33. Sprague Hall, Yale University, College and Wall Streets. (203) 432-4158. Old Lyme Works by Mendelssohn, Haydn and Brahms, presented by Musical Masterworks. Feb. 3 at 5 p.m. and Feb. 4 at 3 p.m. $5 to $30. First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, 2 Ferry Road. (860) 434-2252. Ridgefield Tret Fure, folk. Jan. 28 at 7 p.m. $15 to $20. Temple Shearith Israel, 46 Peaceable Street. (201) 431-6501. Stamford DanceFest 2007: Complexions Contemporary Ballet. Thursday at 8 p.m. $37. ''Student Festival Performance.'' Feb. 4 at 5 p.m. $12 to $24. Rich Forum, Stamford Center for the Arts, 307 Atlantic Street. (203) 325-4466. Stamford ''Music for Harp,'' presented by the Treetops Chamber Music Society, with Lisa Tannenbaum, harp, the Shanghai Quartet and others. Feb. 3 and 4 at 4 p.m. $20 to $50. The Treetops Studio, 359 Merriebrook Lane. (203) 979-6051. Storrs Joshua Bell, violin. Tuesday at 8 p.m. $28 to $40. ''Gospel Festival 2007,'' with Vickie Winans and others. Feb. 3 at 5 p.m. $25. Jorgensen Center for the Performing Arts, 2132 Hillside Road, University of Connecticut. (860) 486-4226. Wallingford Sugarland, country. Thursday at 7:30 p.m. $38 to $48. Chevrolet Theater, 95 South Turnpike Road. (203) 265-1501. Wilton ''Prevailing Winds of Connecticut,'' presented by Ralph Kirmser, oboe, with a woodwind quintet. Jan. 28 at 4 p.m. Wilton Library, 137 Old Ridgefield Road. (203) 762-3950. THEATER Hartford ''Fences,'' by August Wilson, directed by Jonathan Wilson. Through Feb. 11. $25 to $45. Hartford Stage, 50 Church Street. (860) 527-5151. New Britain ''Bat Boy: The Musical'' by Keythe Farley, Brian Flemming and Laurence O'Keefe, directed by Philip D. Vetro. Through Feb. 10. $20. Hole in the Wall Theater, 116 Main Street. (860) 229-3049. New Haven ''The Cocktail Hour'' by A. R. Gurney, directed by Kim Rubinstein. Through Feb. 4. $30 to $60. Long Wharf Theater, 222 Sargent Drive. (203) 787-4282. New Haven ''Live Radio/Vintage Suspense,'' adapted from works by Gunter Eich and Lucille Fletcher, directed by Naomi Okuyama. Thursday through Feb. 3. $10 to $15. Yale Cabaret, 217 Park Street. (203) 432-1566. New Haven ''In the Continuum,'' written and performed by Danai Gurira and Nikkole Salter, directed by Robert O'Hara. Through Feb. 10. $20 to $40. Yale Repertory Theater, 1120 Chapel Street. (203) 432-1234. Ridgefield ''Loss of Color'' by Timothy Ford, staged reading. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Free. Ridgefield Theater Barn, 37 Halpin Lane. (203) 431-9850. Stratford ''Rounding Third'' by Richard Dresser, presented by Square One Theater Company. Friday through Feb. 17. $16; seniors and students, $15. Stratford Theater, 2422 Main Street. (203) 375-8778. Torrington The Nancy Marine Studio Theater Season: ''The Odd Couple.'' Friday through Feb. 11. $10.50 to $15.50. Warner Theater, 68 Main Street. (860) 489-7180. Wallingford ''Winter Cabaret,'' student production. Jan. 28. $10; seniors, $9. Paul Mellon Arts Center, Christian Street. (203) 697-2261. West Hartford ''Lend Me a Tenor'' by Ken Ludwig, directed by Howard Hirsch. Through Feb. 4. $25; students, $10. Park Road Playhouse, 244 Park Road. (860) 586-8500. Westport ''Selected Shorts,'' readings by John Shea, Isaiah Sheffer and Tazewell Thompson. Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. $15 to $25. Westport Country Playhouse, 25 Powers Court. (203) 227-4177. Westport ''Spinning Into Butter'' by Rebecca Gilman. Friday through Feb. 18. $12 to $16. Westport Town Hall, 110 Myrtle Avenue. (203) 226-1983. SPOKEN WORD Fairfield ''Borders of the Mind,'' psychic show presented by Joshua Kane. Feb. 3 at 3 and 8 p.m.; Feb. 4 at 3 p.m. $15; children, $12. Quick Center for the Arts, 1073 North Benson Road. (203) 254-4010. Old Greenwich Lawrence Malkin, author of ''Kruger's Men.'' Tuesday at 7:30 p.m. Julia Chiapetta, author of ''Breast Cancer: The Notebook.'' Wednesday at 7:30 p.m. Arcadia Coffee Company, 20 Arcadia Road. (203) 637-8766. COMEDY Wallingford Lewis Black. Feb. 3 at 8 p.m. $38. Chevrolet Theater, 95 South Turnpike Road. (203) 265-1501. FOR CHILDREN Bridgeport ''Oliver Twist,'' a new version of Dickens's classic set to pop music, directed by Bert Bernardi. Through Feb. 18. $13.50. Downtown Cabaret Theater, 263 Golden Hill Street. (203) 576-1636. Cold Spring Harbor ''Scrimshaw,'' create a keepsake box. Ages 6 to 12. Jan. 28 at 1 p.m. $7; members, $2.50; reservations required. Whaling Museum, Route 25A. (631) 367-3418. Glastonbury ''Aquatic Mammals: Muskrats,'' learn about muskrats and hike to find them. Ages 5 to 10. Tuesday at 4 p.m. $13; members, $10. The Connecticut Audubon Society Center at Glastonbury, 1361 Main Street. (860) 633-8402. Stamford ''Pajama Storytime,'' stories and songs; wear pajamas. Ages 3 and up. Monday at 7 p.m. Free. Ferguson Library, 115 Vine Road. (203) 964-1000. Waterbury ''Cam Jansen,'' children's musical adapted from the books by David A. Adler, presented by the Young People's Theater. Feb. 3 at 3 p.m. $7. John F. Kennedy High School Auditorium, Highland Avenue. (203) 577-2377. Waterbury ''Alice'' by Whoopi Goldberg, adapted by Kim Hines. Ages 5 to 12. Wednesday at 10 a.m. and noon. $8. Palace Theater of Connecticut, 100 East Main Street. (203) 755-4700. West Hartford ''Color Play: The Art and Science of Color and Light,'' explore light and holographic refraction. Ages 12 and under. Through June 17. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. The Children's Museum, 950 Trout Brook Drive. (860) 231- 2824. Woodbridge ''Super Bowl Sunday Magic Show,'' presented by Ed Popielarczyk. Feb. 4 at 2 p.m. Free. Woodbridge Library, 10 Newton Road. (203) 389-3439. MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES Brookfield ''The Sound of Earth: Ceramic Musical Instruments,'' works by Rod Kendall, Susan Rawcliffe and others. Friday through March 18. Reception: Feb. 4, 2 to 4 p.m. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Brookfield Craft Center, 286 Whisconier Road. (203) 775-4526. Fairfield ''Romare Bearden: Scenes From the Portfolios.'' Through Feb. 26. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. The Gallery of Contemporary Art, Sacred Heart University, 5151 Park Avenue. (203) 365-7650. Fairfield ''Multiple Visions: Traveling Art Boxes from Argentina, Mexico and Uruguay,'' works by more than 20 artists. Through March 11. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Thomas J. Walsh Art Galley, 1073 North Benson Road. (203) 254-4000. Greenwich ''Black and White Since 1960,'' 25 large-scale etchings and lithographs from the collection of Reba and Dave Williams, with works by Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg and others. Through Feb. 25. ''In Response to Place: Photographs From the Nature Conservancy's Last Great Places,'' photographs by William Wegman, Annie Liebovitz, Lee Friedlander and others. Through Jan. 28. $7; seniors and students, $6; children 5 and under, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Bruce Museum of Arts and Sciences, 1 Museum Drive. (203) 869-0376. Hartford ''Crewel World,'' exhibition of textiles embroidered using the crewel technique. Through Feb. 25. ''Soul Food: African-American Cooking and Creativity,'' art and artifacts exploring Southern cooking and culture; presented by the Amistad Center for Art and Culture. Through April 22. ''Picasso to Pop: Aspects of Modern Art,'' exhibition of the museum's holdings from many 20th-century genres. Through Nov. 18. $3 to $10; members and children 12 and under, free. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; first Thursdays of the month, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, 600 Main Street. (860) 838-4058. Mashantucket ''Booming Out: Mohawk Ironworkers Build New York,'' photographs and sculpture documenting the Mohawk sky-walking construction tradition passed through six generations. Through May 27. $10 to $15; children under 6, free. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; last admission, 3 p.m. Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center, 110 Pequot Trail. (800) 411-9671. Middletown ''Xanadu,'' video installation by Robert Boyd. Through March 4. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Ezra and Cecile Zilkha Gallery, Wesleyan University, 283 Washington Terrace. (860) 685-3355. Middletown ''Tibet's Living Art: Paintings by Jampa Tsondue.'' Through March 9. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Mansfield Freeman Center for East Asian Studies Gallery, Wesleyan University, 343 Washington Terrace. (860) 685-2330. New Canaan ''Four/Play,'' works by Susan Sharp. Through Feb. 4. Vassos Gallery, 1037 Silvermine Road. (203) 966-9700. New Haven ''Loud,'' juried exhibition with works by artists who are visually or aurally loud. Through Feb. 4. Free. Hours: Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Arts + Literature Laboratory, 319 Peck Street. (203) 671-5175. New Haven ''Howard Hodgkin: Paintings 1992-2007.'' Thursday through April 1. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Yale Center for British Art, 1080 Chapel Street. (203) 432-2800. New Haven ''Jasper Johns: From Plate to Print.'' Through April 1. ''Making a Mark: Four Contemporary Artists in Print,'' prints by Enrique Chagoya, Carroll Dunham, Jane Hammond and Kiki Smith. Through April 1. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Yale University Art Gallery. (203) 432-9525. New London ''femme brut(e),'' works by female artists including May Stevens, Nancy Spero, Barbara Kruger and others. Through Feb. 4. $3 and $4; children 6 and under, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Lyman Allyn Art Museum, 625 Williams Street. (860) 443-2545. New Milford Michael and Helen Cherney, acrylics, watercolors, oils and pastels. Through Feb. 10. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. New Milford Public Library, 24 Main Street. (860) 355-1191. Old Lyme ''The Freedom Business: Connecticut Landscapes Through the Eyes of Venture Smith,'' poems by Marilyn Nelson paired with paintings from the museum's collection. Through June 24. ''A Collective Endeavor: Three Decades of Acquisitions.'' Through March 25. $4 to $8; under 6, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5p. Florence Griswold Museum, 96 Lyme Street. (860) 434-5542. Ridgefield ''Bitter Fruit,'' photographs by Paul Fusco. Through Feb. 25. ''No Reservations: Native American History and Culture in Contemporary Art.'' Through Feb. 25. $7; seniors and students, $4; members, K-12 teachers and children under 18, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, 258 Main Street. (203) 438-4519. Ridgefield ''History of the Present: African-American Self-Taught Artists of the South,'' works by seven outsider artists, including Thornton Dial, Mary Proctor and others. Feb. 3 through March 3. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Ridgefield Guild of Artists Gallery, 34 Halpin Lane. (203) 438-8863. Storrs ''Printerly Prints,'' exhibition of printmakers including Brad Brown, Jane Hammond and others. Through Feb. 23. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Contemporary Art Galleries, 830 Bolton Road, University of Connecticut, Storrs Campus. (860) 486-1511. Storrs ''Intemperate Times: Kathe Kollwitz, 1918-1934.'' Through May 6. ''Landscape: Fact and Fiction,'' landscape photography by John Pfahl, Deborah Bright and others. Through March 2. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 4:30 p.m. William Benton Museum of Art, 245 Glenbrook Road. (860) 486-4520. West Hartford ''From Theater and Teahouse: Actors and Courtesans in Japanese Woodblock Prints,'' historical works by various artists. Through Jan. 28. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. St. Joseph College Art Gallery, 1678 Asylum Avenue. (860) 231-5399. Westport ''Art and the Good Earth: As Seen Through the Painter's Eye,'' works by 14 artists. Through May 11. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Westport Historical Society, 25 Avery Place. (203) 224-1424.

docs.snippet: Weeks       This   Last   On       Week   Week   List   FICTION                1       1   PLUM LOVIN', by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) A mysterious man in Stephanie Plum's life helps her track down a matchmaker who skipped bail.         ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Weeks This Last On Week Week List FICTION 1 1 PLUM LOVIN', by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) A mysterious man in Stephanie Plum's life helps her track down a matchmaker who skipped bail. 2 3 9 CROSS, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Alex Cross, retired from the F.B.I., has a chance to track a rapist who may have murdered his wife. 3 1 16 FOR ONE MORE DAY, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $21.95.) A troubled man gets a last chance to reconnect and restore his relationship with his dead mother. 4 2 2 THE HUNTERS, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer seeks the killers of a shady American diplomat murdered in Uruguay. 5 5 3 SHADOW DANCE, by Julie Garwood. (Ballantine, $25.95.) A businesswoman encounters danger and romance while investigating an ancient Scottish feud. 6 1 EXILE, by Richard North Patterson. (Holt, $26.) A San Francisco lawyer defends a Palestinian woman accused of assassinating the Israeli prime minister. 7 4 7 NEXT, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) The author of ''Jurassic Park'' describes a not-too-distant future when genetic engineering runs amok. 8* 8 3 STALEMATE, by Iris Johansen. (Bantam, $26.) The forensic sculptor Eve Duncan travels to Colombia to identify a skull for a shady arms dealer. 9 6 11 DEAR JOHN, by Nicholas Sparks. (Warner, $24.99.) An unlikely romance between a soldier and an idealistic young woman is tested in the aftermath of 9/11. 10 7 6 HANNIBAL RISING, by Thomas Harris. (Delacorte, $27.95.) The childhood and adolescence of Hannibal Lecter shed light on how he became ''death's prodigy.'' 11* 11 6 THE BOLEYN INHERITANCE, by Philippa Gregory. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) Politics and treachery in the court of Henry VIII, narrated by three women, two of them his sometime wives. 12 10 2 THE CAT WHO HAD 60 WHISKERS, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam, $23.95.) The columnist Jim Qwilleran and his cats probe a mysterious death. 13 9 7 TREASURE OF KHAN, by Clive Cussler and Dirk Cussler. (Putnam, $27.95.) In his 19th adventure, Dirk Pitt confronts a murderous Mongolian tycoon who manipulates the oil market and knows Genghis Khan's secret . 14 12 7 BROTHER ODD, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) With his ability to see the spirits of the dead, Odd Thomas, a character in two previous novels by Koontz, heads off a catastrophe at a monastery . 15 1 WEB OF EVIL, by J. A. Jance. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $25.95.) Alison Reynolds, a former Los Angeles news anchor, comes under suspicion when her about-to-be-ex husband is murdered. 16* 13 10 WILD FIRE, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.99.) Detective John Corey and his wife, an F.B.I. agent, help to foil a nuclear plot against the United States. Weeks This Last On Week Week List NONFICTION 1 1 13 THE AUDACITY OF HOPE, by Barack Obama. (Crown, $25.) The Illinois junior senator proposes that Americans move beyond their political divisions. 2 2 14 THE INNOCENT MAN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) Grisham's first nonfiction book concerns a man sentenced to death for a crime he did not commit. 3 3 65 MARLEY & ME, by John Grogan. (Morrow, $29.95 and $21.95.) A newspaper columnist and his wife learn some life lessons from their neurotic dog. 4 11 2 ABOUT ALICe, by Calvin Trillin. (Random House, $14.95.) The New Yorker writer's recollections of his deceased wife. 5 6 8 PALESTINE PEACE NOT APARTHEID, by Jimmy Carter. (Simon & Schuster, $27.) The former president calls for revitalizing the peace process. 6 4 17 THE GOD DELUSION, by Richard Dawkins. (Houghton Mifflin, $27.) An Oxford scientist asserts that belief in God is irrational. 7* 5 24 I FEEL BAD ABOUT MY NECK, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $19.95.) A witty look at aging from a novelist and screenwriter (''When Harry Met Sally''). 8 7 16 CULTURE WARRIOR, by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $26.) The host of ''The O'Reilly Factor'' describes a culture war between traditionalists and secular-progressives. 9 9 93 THE WORLD IS FLAT, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) A columnist for The New York Times analyzes 21st-century economics and foreign policy. 10 8 88 FREAKONOMICS, by Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner. (Morrow, $27.95.) A maverick scholar and a journalist apply economic theory to everything from cheating sumo wrestlers to abortion and the falling birth rate. 11 1 THE SECRET LIVES OF MEN AND WOMEN, by Frank Warren. (Regan, $21.95.) More postcard confessions from the PostSecret Project. 12 3 BLOOD AND THUNDER, by Hampton Sides. (Doubleday, $26.95.) A history of the American conquest of the West, focused on Kit Carson's defeat of the Navajo. 13* 1 ON ''THE WEALTH OF NATions, by P. J. O'Rourke. (Atlantic Monthly, $21.95.) The author of ''Give War a Chance'' reads (and praises) Adam Smith. 14 2 SEA OF THUNDER, by Evan Thomas. (Simon & Schuster, $27.) The naval war in the South Pacific, 1941-45. 15 10 13 I LIKE YOU, by Amy Sedaris. (Warner, $27.99.) A wacky approach to entertaining from the actress and playwright. 16* 1 PRIME GREEN, by Robert Stone. (Ecco/HarperCollins, $25.95.) A memoir of the '60s from the author of ''Dog Soldiers.'' Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Jan. 13, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers, statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

docs.snippet: “Squinting into the horizon he would imagine topsails appearing, followed by mainsails and a dark hull, and fantasize about life on board the square-riggers during the Great Age of Sail . . .”
docs.lead_paragraph: “Squinting into the horizon he would imagine topsails appearing, followed by mainsails and a dark hull, and fantasize about life on board the square-riggers during the Great Age of Sail . . .”

docs.snippet: After more than a decade overseas, Claudio Reyna will come home to play for the Red Bulls’ as one of the team's two designated players.
docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a decade overseas, Claudio Reyna will come home to play for the Red Bulls’ as one of the team's two designated players.
